div1.p: Peabody describes his research on Reed and tells Hench where the research materials may be found.

div1.head: Letter from James E. Peabody to Philip Showalter Hench, September 10, 1940
div1.opener:
281 LOWELL AVENUE
NEWTONVILLE, MASSACHUSETTS
Sept. 10, 1940.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Dr. Hench:-
div1.p:
Your letter of Aug. 26th. has been
forwarded to me by the American
Museum of Natural History. I am
much pleased to learn of your
interest in the heroic story of the con-
quest of Yellow Fever. I take pleasure
in sending you under another
cover the pamphlet to which you
refer, together with some other mim-
eographed material that may
interest you.

When our N. Y. Biology Ass'n. Com-
mittee finished its work, at the
suggestion of Surgeon General
Ireland, I turned over to the
Welch Medical Library in Baltimore
all the material we had collected
in the campaign which finally
resulted in the passage of the
Yellow Fever Pension Bill by Con-
gress. You might find some
correspondence and original papers
there that would be helpful. I
received a good many letters from
Mrs. Walter Reed, Mrs. Jesse Lazear,
Mrs. James Carroll, Mrs. Agramonte
and her daughter, Gen. Keane,
Gen. Ireland, Kissinger, Moran
and others. You might find in
the collection the article “The Republic
Remembers” to which you refer.
I am quite sure the librarian
would be glad to let you borrow
this material, should you care
to do so. By a curious coincidence
I had Dr. Lazear's son in my
biology class in the University
of California Summer Session & I met his mother and sister.

I am quite sure the American
Museum in N. Y. has a limited
collection of lantern slides. I
had assembled two boxes of slides
on this subject which I have
281 LOWELL AVENUE
NEWTONVILLE, MASSACHUSETTS
used many times in the lectures
I have given I retired from my
position as Head of the Biology
Department in New York City, ten
years ago, my daughter, Dr. Eliza-
beth B. Peabody, As a member of
the Biology Department of Wilson
College, Chambersburg, Pa., has
naturally became interested in this
Yellow Fever story, so I have
given my slides to her. I am
confident she would be glad to
cooperate with you in any way
she can. On her way back from
her work at the Barrs Colorado
Island Laboratory this summer,
she spent sometime in Cuba
and there met Mr. Moran.

You are certainly taking great
pains in the preparation of your
address. You may be sure I am
glad indeed to learn of this move-

ment to perpetuate the memory
of a martyr in the cause of science
of whom we may well be proud.
If your address is printed in a
separate, both my daughter and
I would be very glad to receive
a copy. If I can be of further
assistance please call upon me.
div1.closer: Very truly yours. James E. Peabody.
